title: As a D3 Vinegar main, I have a proposal
body: Get rid of the enemy AP scaling on his ult, and give Vinegar 1.5 AP ratio on it for compensation. It may be too much, try 1.4, but you get the point. The ultimate, as of now, does little but limit Vinegar's targeting choice. Giving his ult a flat Ap ratio against all champions will aid him in dealing with AD assassins mid, which are awful enough for him as is. Ever tried dealing with Talon or Zed as Vinegar? He has zero reliability against any of them, and the one skill that can hit them for sure will do jack squat because they have no AP. By the same token, enemy AP mids won't feel like crap whenever they buy large amounts of AP. Anti-mage was never Vinegar's true identity, it was always burst mage, and that means he bursts whoever he pleases.

replies.body:
I've seen this request (or ones pretty similar to it) a few times in the last week now. Just to get another read...

> Anti-mage was never Vinegar's true identity, it was always burst mage, and that means he bursts whoever he pleases.

How does everyone feel about the above statement?

His ult is the only thing really making him anti mage, there are other champions who do a better job at being anti mage, {{champion:31}} {{champion:3}} {{champion:38}} {{champion:25}} {{champion:13}} just off the top of my head. His identity as a burst mage however, is far more ingrained into his entire kit, and if he's going to burst 1 person and then have most of his burst on cool down for the rest of the team fight then limiting him to bursting the AP carry hurts his useability quite a bit.
Yeah, this seems to be the consensus of most everyone else that has responded as well.

If I had to choose one, I'd say "burst mage" over "mage burster". His post-DFG "compensation buffs" turned him into much more of a poke mage than a burst mage, and I think it would be good to consider some further changes that might make him feel bursty again. (Mostly, I think his ragecage needs to do something more interesting. I think Riot's underestimating how fundamentally the changes broke his kit and reduced his strategic decision potential, but that's a topic for another thread.) I mean, sure, he's still got a "bursty" R, but it's a very uninteresting burst ability: push button, delete enemy. That's how non-Veigar players might have *parodied* old Veigar, but it differed sharply from actual old Veigar. With new Veigar, there's no double-or-nothing question of whether or not to split ult and DFG (because DFG is gone), or whether to use the stun to pin down an enemy squishy or use it for the team (because the new stun is more "toss it on the ground and hope somebody accidentally walks into it").

Really, though, I think he's both. I think he should retain his "anti-mage" tone with his ult. At least historically, a big part of Veigar's very flavorful theme was that he was an extremely weak laner who got kicked around all lanephase, then took his vengeance later on. It was very satisfying, and thematically appropriate, for Veigar to get an extra power surge when targeting the enemy mid that terrorized him for the early part of the game. It also synergized nicely with the itemization situation.

For example, a somewhat common pattern was "enemy mage beats the hell out of Veigar early on, enemy mage gets really cocky and builds pure glass cannon with visions of pentakills dancing in their head, Veigar's team rages at Veigar for feeding, and then, suddenly, BLAM! Veigar incinerates the enemy mage with one shot, quite literally killing them with the AP items they bought with proceeds from tormenting Veigar in lane. BAHAHAHAHA! The tables have turned, and Veigar shows NO MERCY!" It really brought a psychological, even lore-informed element to his playstyle. You could just imagine Veigar's rage amping up the spell. It also presented a real choice for the enemy mid: double-down on their early success and build glass cannon, with the understanding that they had better be careful about their positioning, or build more defensively, resisting the temptation to buy four deathcaps and try to carry the game single-handed. In effect, it asked the enemy mid, in Veigar's screechy yordle-voice: "Do you feel lucky? Well, do you?" Perhaps more pointedly, it asks: "Do you think you beat me up in lane because you're just better than me? Then build glass cannon and rely on your superior skill to avoid an EWQR. Not sure about that? Then take the safe road and build some defense."

To be honest, new Veigar feels like "pretty okay mage who passively farms all lanephase from relative safety, then in the midgame does some moderate poke damage to the enemy team and maybe bursts someone if they're low". I'm pretty :\ about that.

The problem I see is that his ult is now a very "flat" ability. If they amp it up, he might be strong, but not in an interesting way. With old Veigar, there were some strategic decision-points on the way to bursting someone:

* Positioning: The dance of "when can I move forward to throw my stun without getting killed by their front line?" (I suppose this is still somewhat relevant.)
* Damage splitting: Whether to stack DFG and ult for a sure kill, or go double-or-nothing and split DFG and ult in the hopes of killing two squishies. (DFG isn't around anymore, so this doesn't come up.)
* Stun usage: Whether to use stun to lock the enemy mage down, probably with the outer edge, and make sure everything hits, or to save it for when the teamfight really begins, stunning multiple lower-value targets to help your team. (His stun is now a "throw somewhere and hope somebody walks into it accidentally" ability, rather than an ability that can be landed or missed.)

So I'm a little wary of just giving his ult more power without fixing these deeper problems. (That said, I was pretty annoyed that these nerfs were announced as "compensation buffs" for losing DFG; a real form of compensation for losing DFG would be to amp up ult damage.)

I feel like Yasuo's more of an Anti-Mage between his shield, dash, and wind wall than Veigar. (Seriously, Wind Wall is one of the best Anti-Mage tools in the game.)

Veigar's Ultimate is one of two things in regards to AP Opponents:

* **Win Lane Harder**: You let me passively farm forever, then my jungler came and we killed you a few times. You're getting your big AP items, but I'm getting more use out of them sending you back to the fountain faster. I make you scared to come close to a team fight.
* **Come Back Mechanic**: You beat me to a bloody pulp in laning phase. I've got no farm, no kills, and I'm feeding bad. You're spiraling out of control, confidently charging into team fights, but in the nanosecond before you can 100-0 me, I fire my ult at you and we both die. My team now has a chance, and I start to slowly make up my lost ground.

The change would strengthen the **Win Lane Harder** situation, while completely removing the **Come Back Mechanic** situation. I'm not sure if that's a good thing, a bad thing, or just a thing to consider.

(In fact; Veigar doesn't even have specific hatred for anything or anyone) Veigar isn't really all that reliable against better players either, despite his strongest ability being point-and-click. Even more so if you pick first in draft pick. In addition, since Veigar's stun isn't reliable and since Veigar's W is probably the least reliable skill in the game as a result, having his ult only work optimally on certain kinds of champions feels really... Limiting. It feels like a waste to ult an Ashe or a Zed, but you don't usually have a choice when the enemy APC has less than 200 AP and more MR than their tank.
